content: Choose your restaurant’s concept. To begin with, determine what kind of cuisine you’d like to offer. Then think about who your clientele will be, and consider what price range you’d like to fall in. Finally, take the location of your restaurant into consideration. Use this information to come up with a simple, concise concept for your restaurant. [1] Take inspiration from the restaurants and businesses around you to develop a sense of what works in this area. Decide what your menu items will be. Make a list of the 10-12 menu items you know you can do best. This should form the basis of your menu. Select items that fit with your restaurant concept. If you are a new restaurant, avoid including more than 10-12 items at first. [2] If you’re restaurant is open all day, you may want to have a morning menu (breakfast/lunch) and an evening menu (lunch/dinner). Don’t forget about beverages! Add a few high-end or speciality items. Choose 2-3 items that are a little more expensive. Try for items that fit within yout restaurant concept, but that are not offered at other places nearby. [3] Some ideas include: A premium cut of steak An exotic fish Dishes that a little harder to make, such as Spanish paella Specialty entrées for two Offer some “house favorites. ” Select 2-3 items that you know you make well, and you believe will be good seller. These should be items at mid-level price point. Label these items with a star or other symbol that indicate they are a “best seller” or “chef’s choice.” [4] Create names for the items on your menu. Each food item on the menu will need to be called something. Marketing research has shown that customers tend to gravitate toward creative names. Rather than calling your hamburger simply “hamburger,” why not name a speciality burger “The Mona Lisa” or “The Couch Potato”? [5] Make sure your menu names fit with the concept of your restaurant. For instance, an upscale bistro might not want comedic food names. Write down all your menu items in a spreadsheet. Sit down and list every single item that will appear on your menu. This is important to do even if you are working from an existing menu. It will help you to best organize and categorize all of your items. This works best if you use an Excel Spreadsheet or Google sheet. If you don’t have access to any kind of spreadsheet, you can do this on a sheet of paper. Order your menu in a logical way. Determine about 3 major sections of your menu. If each section has more than 10 items, divide each section into 1-2 subsections. Then come up with a logical way to order your menu items. The most common way is chronologically, meaning that breakfast items come first and desserts come last. Place all of this info into your spreadsheet. [6] Section or subsection ideas include: Breakfast Appetizers Lunch Main courses Soup and salad Pasta Vegetarian Specialty Beverages and/or cocktails Describe each dish in about 10 words . The food items themselves should have descriptive titles. For instance, “burger” doesn’t sound like much, but “Juicy Burger with Arugula and Horseradish Aioli” will get your reader's’ attention. After that, include a brief description of all the ingredients in the dish. You might say: “Quarter-pound all-beef patty with arugula, creamy aioli, grilled mushrooms, ripe tomatoes, and pepper jack or Swiss cheese on a brioche bun.” [7] Make a note if any of the following apply: The dish is hotter/spicier than most of the other dishes on the menu. The dish contains any ingredients to which some people are severely allergic (e.g. peanuts). The dish caters to a group with special dietary needs (vegan, vegetarian, gluten-free, etc.) Calculate your gross margins and markup percentages. Think about what you’d like to charge for each item. Then figure out the unit cost of each menu item by adding together the cost of ingredients plus overhead costs. Subtract the unit cost of each item from your potential menu price. Divide your gross margin amount by your unit cost to get your markup percentage. [8] Let’s say the unit cost for fried chicken is $10, and you plan to charge $16 for it. Subtract $10 from $16 to get $6. Divide your gross margin amount ($6) by your unit cost ($10) to get your markup percentage (60%). Adjust menu prices to maximize your profits. Before you finalize menu prices, keep in mind the markup percentages of these items, and what margins you should be making. Make sure your dishes are priced correctly and, if they're not, consider redoing the ingredients list or changing the recipe so you're more prepared to make a profit. In general: [9] Here are some guidelines: Appetizers and desserts will have low unit costs, and high markup percentages. Steak and other expensive meats will only have about a 50% markup percentage. Pasta dishes and salads can have 80-85% markup percentages. Alcohol prices will vary widely. Try to keep your markup percentages between 50 and 70%. Consider the average income of folks in your area. Keep your average price around what locals will be able to pay for a meal. To figure out what most guests are willing to pay, take a look at the prices on your competitors' menus. What do their least and most expensive items costs? What is the average price of their menu items? For instance, do you think your customers can afford to buy a $30 entree, or would they stick to a $15-20 range? End prices on whole dollar amounts and avoid using monetary symbols. Certain design elements can encourage customers to spend a little more. Avoid ending prices on $0.99, and avoid adding dollar signs to your menu. [10] Browse menu templates to get ideas. There are many online templates (for free or for purchase), as well as entire websites dedicated to creating restaurant menus. Even if you have a good sense of what you want, looking through different templates can inspire you or focus your design goals. Choose 1-2 templates that you really like. If you have access to Microsoft word, Powerpoint, or any Adobe Suite programs, there are many menu templates in these formats available online. Websites like Canva and Must Have Menus offer some free templates, and others for a fee. Programs like iMenu offer drag-and-drop menu templates, but programs like this are not usually free. Choose a color scheme that matches the style of the restaurant. For a fancy restaurant, dark colors will convey a sense of seriousness and professionalism. At a casual restaurant, warm, muted colors will look appropriately inviting. At a restaurant with a young clientele or a zanier theme, bright colors will usually make the most sense. Unless you’re not happy with the interior design or plan on changing it, making the menus match (or at least complement) the restaurant itself is probably the safest bet. [11] Select a presentation style that fits with your restaurant’s concept. Your menu could be horizontal or vertical. It could be housed on a wooden clipboard, placed into a binder, presented as a placemat, or any number of other options. [12] A family diner might use a menu placemat. A brunch spot might use little wooden clipboards to present menus. An upscale bistro might have folding menus encased in clear binders. Use a menu template for an easier menu design. Once you have the look you want, look for a menu template online and plug all of your information in as-needed. Opt for a simple design of possible, and try 2 templates before sticking with one. Some other common things to keep in mind as you choose your template: [13] Keep your fonts simple. Don’t use more than 3 fonts on the menu. Check to see if any of the pages seems lopsided. Try to provide the same amount of information on each page. You can find menu templates on Microsoft Word, Google Docs, or online. Consider hiring a graphic designer . If you have the means, hiring a professional designer can be a good option. A designer will be able to customize your menu and make sure it fits within your restaurant’s overall concept. [14] Post an add on Freelancer.com, Linkedin, Craigslist, or another site. Include as many specifics about the project as you can. Depending on the specifics of your design a professional designer should cost anywhere from $300 to $500. Take pictures of the food yourself to create an appetizing menu. Shoot in natural light on an overcast day, and in front of a neutral background. Choose brightly colored food items and think about how you arrange your food. Try to create a balance picture. If possible, use a nice camera. Also, if possible, use photo editing software to enhance your images. [15] If you want to hire a food photographer instead, post an add on Freelancer.com or Craigslist, and expect to pay between $10 and $50 per image. [16] Forego food images to keep your menu simple. If you're struggling to get appetizing pictures, or don't think your menu will have enough space to fit in images, skip the images altogether. Remember: not every menu needs images to shine! [17] Look over the rough design and ask for people’s opinions. Evaluate the menu draft and see if you like it. Ask for feedback from 2-3 people, including at least 1 person outside of your industry. Make sure that everyone involved (the restaurant owner, manager, chef, and so on) takes a look at the design and content. You could ask: "Is the menu easy to read?" "Do you like the color scheme?" "Does the design fit with the restaurant concept?" "Does the design seem too busy?" "Do you like the ?" "Are there any mistakes or typos?" Determine how many menus you need based on the number of seats. Think about how many seats you have in your restaurant. Take this number and add 10-25%. This is the number of menus you will need. Go for a lower percentage if your menus will be durable and easy to clean. Go for a higher percentage if your restaurant serves messy food, serves a lot of children, or is made from less/durable more difficult to clean material. If you will be using disposable menus (e.g., placemats) determine the number of customers you plan to have each day and multiply that by the length of time you want this round of menus to last. You will reorder menus as needed. Proofread the menu before printing. Go through the entire menu with a fine-tooth comb, as errors in the menu send a poor message about the quality of the establishment. You could also hire a professional editor, just in case you missed anything. Print the menu with a high-quality printer. Send your finished menu to a professional to be printed. Avoid printing menus on a home printer unless you have a professional-quality laser printer. The cost of professional printing is small compared to the impact of well printed pages. You can send your menu to a chain, like Staples, or a local printing service. Or you can order prints of your menu online. Print a few menus and make sure they are perfect before you place a large order. Bind or package your menus. If you will be presenting your menu by way of a binder, clipboard, or other item, order enough of these to accommodate your menus. Place 1 menu in each holder. If your menu is going to be professionally bound, see if this can be done at the time of printing to save yourself time and money.

<h1 class="firstHeading no_toc"><a href="https://www.wikihow.com/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu">How to Make a Restaurant Menu</a></h1>
<div class="" id="expert_coauthor">
	
	Co-authored by <a class="staff_icon expert_coauthor_link" href="#article_info_section">
		wikiHow Staff</a><span class="ss_pipe">|</span><a class="expert_coauthor_link ss_review" href="#article_info_section">Reader-Approved</a>
<span class="ss_pipe">|</span><a href="#references">17 References</a>
</div>

In this case, several readers have written to tell us that this article was helpful to them, earning it our reader-approved status.
		<a class="sp_learn_more_link" href="/wikiHow:About-wikiHow#Why_should_you_choose_wikiHow_first.3F_sub">Learn more...</a>

<p>A menu is the first thing a customer sees when they come into your restaurant, and the last thing they look at before they order. This makes the menu one of your most valuable marketing tools. As long as you follow some basic guidelines, you can create a sleek restaurant menu that your customers will enjoy!</p>

<h2 class="hidden"><span class="mw-headline" id="Steps">Steps</span></h2>
<a class="anchor" name="Choosing_Your_Menu_Options_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Choosing_Your_Menu_Options">Choosing Your Menu Options</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-1-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-1-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3e/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_d2327b6141" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d2327b6141')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3e/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Choose your restaurant’s concept.</b> To begin with, determine what kind of cuisine you’d like to offer. Then think about who your clientele will be, and consider what price range you’d like to fall in. Finally, take the location of your restaurant into consideration. Use this information to come up with a simple, concise concept for your restaurant.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Take inspiration from the restaurants and businesses around you to develop a sense of what works in this area.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-2-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-2-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/00/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_11562f2941" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_11562f2941')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 2" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/00/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-2-Version-2.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-2-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Decide what your menu items will be.</b> Make a list of the 10-12 menu items you know you can do best. This should form the basis of your menu. Select items that fit with your restaurant concept. If you are a new restaurant, avoid including more than 10-12 items at first.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>If you’re restaurant is open all day, you may want to have a morning menu (breakfast/lunch) and an evening menu (lunch/dinner).</li>
<li>Don’t forget about beverages!</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-3-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-3-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_c21e9d43ed" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c21e9d43ed')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Add a few high-end or speciality items.</b> Choose 2-3 items that are a little more expensive. Try for items that fit within yout restaurant concept, but that are not offered at other places nearby.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup> Some ideas include:

<ul>
<li>A premium cut of steak</li>
<li>An exotic fish</li>
<li>Dishes that a little harder to make, such as Spanish paella</li>
<li>Specialty entrées for two</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-4-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-4-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cd/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_05daf568c5" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_05daf568c5')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 4" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/cd/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-4-Version-2.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-4-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Offer some “house favorites.</b>” Select 2-3 items that you know you make well, and you believe will be good seller. These should be items at mid-level price point. Label these items with a star or other symbol that indicate they are a “best seller” or “chef’s choice.”<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-5-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-5-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/72/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_8646cfd340" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_8646cfd340')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 5" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/72/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-5-Version-2.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-5-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Create names for the items on your menu.</b> Each food item on the menu will need to be called something. Marketing research has shown that customers tend to gravitate toward creative names. Rather than calling your hamburger simply “hamburger,” why not name a speciality burger “The Mona Lisa” or “The Couch Potato”?<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Make sure your menu names fit with the concept of your restaurant. For instance, an upscale bistro might not want comedic food names.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-6-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-6-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a0/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_c13f7478fa" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_c13f7478fa')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/a0/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Write down all your menu items in a spreadsheet.</b> Sit down and list every single item that will appear on your menu. This is important to do even if you are working from an existing menu. It will help you to best organize and categorize all of your items.

<ul>
<li>This works best if you use an Excel Spreadsheet or Google sheet.</li>
<li>If you don’t have access to any kind of spreadsheet, you can do this on a sheet of paper.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-7-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-7-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b4/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_f98dfbb772" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_f98dfbb772')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b4/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-7-Version-2.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-7-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Order your menu in a logical way.</b> Determine about 3 major sections of your menu. If each section has more than 10 items, divide each section into 1-2 subsections. Then come up with a logical way to order your menu items. The most common way is chronologically, meaning that breakfast items come first and desserts come last. Place all of this info into your spreadsheet.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup> Section or subsection ideas include:

<ul>
<li>Breakfast</li>
<li>Appetizers</li>
<li>Lunch</li>
<li>Main courses</li>
<li>Soup and salad</li>
<li>Pasta</li>
<li>Vegetarian</li>
<li>Specialty</li>
<li>Beverages and/or cocktails</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-8.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-8.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-8.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-8.jpg" height="546" id="img_47087fa55b" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_47087fa55b')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/d/d9/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-8.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-8.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 8" class="step_num">8</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_8"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Describe each dish in about 10 words .</b> The food items themselves should have descriptive titles. For instance, “burger” doesn’t sound like much, but “Juicy Burger with Arugula and Horseradish Aioli” will get your reader's’ attention. After that, include a brief description of all the ingredients in the dish. You might say: “Quarter-pound all-beef patty with arugula, creamy aioli, grilled mushrooms, ripe tomatoes, and pepper jack or Swiss cheese on a brioche bun.”<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup> Make a note if any of the following apply:

<ul>
<li>The dish is hotter/spicier than most of the other dishes on the menu.</li>
<li>The dish contains any ingredients to which some people are severely allergic (e.g. peanuts).</li>
<li>The dish caters to a group with special dietary needs (vegan, vegetarian, gluten-free, etc.)</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="methodad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-apsload="1" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="0" data-loaded="0" data-service="dfp" data-slot="" data-viewablerefresh="1">
<div id="methodad"></div>
<script>googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display('methodad'); });</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addBodyAd('methodad')</script>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Pricing_Your_Menu_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Pricing_Your_Menu">Pricing Your Menu</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-9.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-9.jpg" height="546" id="img_3cc585b628" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3cc585b628')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-9.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-9.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Calculate your gross margins and markup percentages.</b> Think about what you’d like to charge for each item. Then figure out the unit cost of each menu item by adding together the cost of ingredients plus overhead costs. Subtract the unit cost of each item from your potential menu price. Divide your gross margin amount by your unit cost to get your markup percentage.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Let’s say the unit cost for fried chicken is $10, and you plan to charge $16 for it. Subtract $10 from $16 to get $6.</li>
<li>Divide your gross margin amount ($6) by your unit cost ($10) to get your markup percentage (60%).</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-10.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-10.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6f/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-10.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-10.jpg" height="546" id="img_7a30d19c5d" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_7a30d19c5d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 10" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6f/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-10.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-10.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Adjust menu prices to maximize your profits.</b> Before you finalize menu prices, keep in mind the markup percentages of these items, and what margins you should be making. Make sure your dishes are priced correctly and, if they're not, consider redoing the ingredients list or changing the recipe so you're more prepared to make a profit. In general:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup> Here are some guidelines:

<ul>
<li>Appetizers and desserts will have low unit costs, and high markup percentages.</li>
<li>Steak and other expensive meats will only have about a 50% markup percentage.</li>
<li>Pasta dishes and salads can have 80-85% markup percentages.</li>
<li>Alcohol prices will vary widely. Try to keep your markup percentages between 50 and 70%.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-11.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-11.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-11.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-11.jpg" height="546" id="img_ecd097e681" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_ecd097e681')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 11" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f7/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-11.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-11.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider the average income of folks in your area.</b> Keep your average price around what locals will be able to pay for a meal. To figure out what most guests are willing to pay, take a look at the prices on your competitors' menus. What do their least and most expensive items costs? What is the average price of their menu items?

<ul>
<li>For instance, do you think your customers can afford to buy a $30 entree, or would they stick to a $15-20 range?</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-12.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-12.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e7/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-12.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-12.jpg" height="546" id="img_fe00e1c8cd" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_fe00e1c8cd')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 12" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e7/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-12.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-12.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">End prices on whole dollar amounts and avoid using monetary symbols.</b> Certain design elements can encourage customers to spend a little more. Avoid ending prices on $0.99, and avoid adding dollar signs to your menu.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
<div id="tocad_wrap">
<div class="wh_ad_inner step_ad" data-adsenseheight="90" data-adsensewidth="728" data-adtargetid="tocad" data-adunitpath="" data-aps-timeout="2000" data-channels="6381149051,3492389196" data-lateload="1" data-loaded="0" data-service="adsense" data-slot="3356467874" data-viewablerefresh="1" id="tocad_outer"><div class="step_ad" id="tocad"></div></div>
<div class="clearall adclear"></div>
<script>WH.desktopAds.addTOCAd('tocad')</script>
</div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Creating_a_Rough_Draft_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Creating_a_Rough_Draft">Creating a Rough Draft</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-13.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-13.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/be/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-13.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-13.jpg" height="546" id="img_5edb9648ff" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_5edb9648ff')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 13" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/be/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-13.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-13.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Browse menu templates to get ideas.</b> There are many online templates (for free or for purchase), as well as entire websites dedicated to creating restaurant menus. Even if you have a good sense of what you want, looking through different templates can inspire you or focus your design goals. Choose 1-2 templates that you really like.

<ul>
<li>If you have access to Microsoft word, Powerpoint, or any Adobe Suite programs, there are many menu templates in these formats available online.</li>
<li>Websites like Canva and Must Have Menus offer some free templates, and others for a fee.</li>
<li>Programs like iMenu offer drag-and-drop menu templates, but programs like this are not usually free.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-14.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-14.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/81/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-14.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-14.jpg" height="546" id="img_e77681fd36" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e77681fd36')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 14" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/81/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-14.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-14.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Choose a color scheme that matches the style of the restaurant.</b> For a fancy restaurant, dark colors will convey a sense of seriousness and professionalism. At a casual restaurant, warm, muted colors will look appropriately inviting. At a restaurant with a young clientele or a zanier theme, bright colors will usually make the most sense. Unless you’re not happy with the interior design or plan on changing it, making the menus match (or at least complement) the restaurant itself is probably the safest bet.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-15.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-15.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-15.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-15.jpg" height="546" id="img_0c4bde3957" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_0c4bde3957')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 15" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ed/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-15.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-15.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Select a presentation style that fits with your restaurant’s concept.</b> Your menu could be horizontal or vertical. It could be housed on a wooden clipboard, placed into a binder, presented as a placemat, or any number of other options.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>A family diner might use a menu placemat.</li>
<li>A brunch spot might use little wooden clipboards to present menus.</li>
<li>An upscale bistro might have folding menus encased in clear binders.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-16.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-16.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-16.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-16.jpg" height="546" id="img_66b60505fe" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_66b60505fe')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 16" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7f/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-16.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-16.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use a menu template for an easier menu design.</b> Once you have the look you want, look for a menu template online and plug all of your information in as-needed. Opt for a simple design of possible, and try 2 templates before sticking with one. Some other common things to keep in mind as you choose your template:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 13" class="reference" id="_ref-13"><a href="#_note-13">[13]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Keep your fonts simple.</li>
<li>Don’t use more than 3 fonts on the menu.</li>
<li>Check to see if any of the pages seems lopsided.</li>
<li>Try to provide the same amount of information on each page.</li>
<li>You can find menu templates on Microsoft Word, Google Docs, or online.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-17.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-17.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4e/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-17.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-17.jpg" height="546" id="img_b05320fa3d" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b05320fa3d')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 17" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4e/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-17.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-17.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Consider hiring a <a href="/Hire-a-Graphic-Designer" title="Hire a Graphic Designer">graphic designer</a>.</b> If you have the means, hiring a professional designer can be a good option. A designer will be able to customize your menu and make sure it fits within your restaurant’s overall concept.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 14" class="reference" id="_ref-14"><a href="#_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Post an add on Freelancer.com, Linkedin, Craigslist, or another site. Include as many specifics about the project as you can.</li>
<li>Depending on the specifics of your design a professional designer should cost anywhere from $300 to $500.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-18.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-18.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-18.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-18.jpg" height="546" id="img_d570b4ccb4" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_d570b4ccb4')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 18" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/08/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-18.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-18.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Take pictures of the food yourself to create an appetizing menu.</b> Shoot in natural light on an overcast day, and in front of a neutral background. Choose brightly colored food items and think about how you arrange your food. Try to create a balance picture. If possible, use a nice camera. Also, if possible, <a href="/Use-Adobe-Photoshop-Tools" title="Use Adobe Photoshop Tools">use photo editing software</a> to enhance your images.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 15" class="reference" id="_ref-15"><a href="#_note-15">[15]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>If you want to hire a food photographer instead, post an add on Freelancer.com or Craigslist, and expect to pay between $10 and $50 per image.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 16" class="reference" id="_ref-16"><a href="#_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-19.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-19.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 19" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/69/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-19.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-19.jpg" height="546" id="img_6bfb6240ec" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_6bfb6240ec')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 19" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/69/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-19.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-19.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 7" class="step_num">7</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_7"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Forego food images to keep your menu simple.</b> If you're struggling to get appetizing pictures, or don't think your menu will have enough space to fit in images, skip the images altogether. Remember: not every menu needs images to shine!<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 17" class="reference" id="_ref-17"><a href="#_note-17">[17]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>
<a class="anchor" name="Choosing_Your_Final_Layout_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock">Part <span>4</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Choosing_Your_Final_Layout">Choosing Your Final Layout</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_4">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-20.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-20.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 20" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-20.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-20.jpg" height="546" id="img_94b1732475" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_94b1732475')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 20" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-20.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-20.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Look over the rough design and ask for people’s opinions.</b> Evaluate the menu draft and see if you like it. Ask for feedback from 2-3 people, including at least 1 person outside of your industry. Make sure that everyone involved (the restaurant owner, manager, chef, and so on) takes a look at the design and content. You could ask:

<ul>
<li>"Is the menu easy to read?"</li>
<li>"Do you like the color scheme?"</li>
<li>"Does the design fit with the restaurant concept?"</li>
<li>"Does the design seem too busy?"</li>
<li>"Do you like the font(s)?"</li>
<li>"Are there any mistakes or typos?"</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-21.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-21.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 21" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-21.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-21.jpg" height="546" id="img_4bdcbf6ebf" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_4bdcbf6ebf')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 21" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/02/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-21.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-21.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Determine how many menus you need based on the number of seats.</b> Think about how many seats you have in your restaurant. Take this number and add 10-25%. This is the number of menus you will need. Go for a lower percentage if your menus will be durable and easy to clean. Go for a higher percentage if your restaurant serves messy food, serves a lot of children, or is made from less/durable more difficult to clean material.

<ul>
<li>If you will be using disposable menus (e.g., placemats) determine the number of customers you plan to have each day and multiply that by the length of time you want this round of menus to last. You will reorder menus as needed.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-22.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-22.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 22" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-22.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-22.jpg" height="546" id="img_bae7dca025" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_bae7dca025')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 22" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/8a/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-22.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-22.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Proofread the menu before printing.</b> Go through the entire menu with a fine-tooth comb, as errors in the menu send a poor message about the quality of the establishment. You could also hire a professional editor, just in case you missed anything.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-23.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-23.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 23" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/60/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-23.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-23.jpg" height="546" id="img_1f3f890b44" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_1f3f890b44')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 23" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/60/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-23.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-23.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Print the menu with a high-quality printer.</b> Send your finished menu to a professional to be printed. Avoid printing menus on a home printer unless you have a professional-quality laser printer. The cost of professional printing is small compared to the impact of well printed pages.

<ul>
<li>You can send your menu to a chain, like Staples, or a local printing service. Or you can order prints of your menu online.</li>
<li>Print a few menus and make sure they are perfect before you place a large order.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage final_li">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-24.jpg?ajax=true&aid=74572" href="#/Image:Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-24.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 24" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-24.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-24.jpg" height="546" id="img_a985e9dd12" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_a985e9dd12')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Make a Restaurant Menu Step 24" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5a/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-24.jpg/aid74572-v4-728px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-24.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_4_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Bind or package your menus.</b> If you will be presenting your menu by way of a binder, clipboard, or other item, order enough of these to accommodate your menus. Place 1 menu in each holder. If your menu is going to be professionally bound, see if this can be done at the time of printing to save yourself time and money.

</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>

<li class="qa_aq qa_block" data-aqid="37411" data-caid="38284" data-cqid="37428" data-qa_inactive="0" data-sqid="200323" data-submitter_id="0" data-verifier_id="0" data-votes_down="6" data-votes_up="35">

<div class="qa_user_name"></div>
<div class="qa_user_label">Community Answer</div>
</div>

<div class="qa_answer answer">Use Microsoft Publisher. It is easy to use and has plenty of templates to get you started; however, it is not free. Another option would be Lucidpress. If any of that is too much to handle, you can design the menu using simpler software like Microsoft Word or Google Docs.</div>

<div class="qa_answer answer">If you are going to serve a lot of children, you might want to make the menus more durable. <input id="qa_asked_question" maxlength="200" placeholder="What do you need to know? We'll do our best to find the answer." type="text"/><div id="qa_asked_count">200 characters left</div>
<input id="qa_email" placeholder="Email address (optional)" type="text"/><div id="qa_email_prompt">Include your email address to get a message when this question is answered.</div>
<a class="button primary" id="qa_submit_button">Submit</a>
</div>
<!--  Template for rendering a submitted question -->
<script id="qa_submitted_question_item" type="text/x-handlebars-template">
				<li class="qa_sq" data-sqid="{{id}}">
	<div class="qa_divider"></div>
	<div class="qa_li_container">
		<div class="qa_bullet"></div>
		<div class="qa_sq_question">
			<div class="qa_q_txt">{{{text}}}</div>
			<div class="qa_editor_tools">
				<a class="qa_edit_submitted {{#qa_desktop}}button secondary{{/qa_desktop}}">{{qa_curate}}</a>
				{{^mobile_anon_user}}
				<a class="qa_flag_submitted" data-type="sq_flag">{{qa_flag}}</a>
				<a class="qa_ignore_submitted" data-type="sq_ignore">{{qa_ignore}}</a>
				{{/mobile_anon_user}}
			</div>
		</div>
	</div>
</li>

			</script><!--  Template for answer confirmation  --><script id="qa_answer_confirmation" type="text/x-handlebars-template">
				<div class="qa_answer_confirmation">

	<span class="x_button"></span>

	<div class="qa_answer_confirmation_response">
		<span class="qa_checkmark"></span>
		<div class="qa_social_login_heading standalone">{{qa_proposed_answer_confirmation}}</div>
	</div>

</div>


			</script><!--  Template form for creating/updating a curated question  --><script id="qa_question_edit_form" type="text/x-handlebars-template">
				<div class="qa_aq_edit_form">
	<div class="qa_aq_edit_form_status"></div>
	<textarea class="qa_cq_text" spellcheck="true" placeholder="{{qa_edit_form_question_placeholder}}">{{qa_edit_form_question}}</textarea>
	<div class="qa_invalid_msg qa_cq_text_error qap_char_limit">{{qa_cq_text_error}}</div>
	<textarea class="qa_ca_text" spellcheck="true" placeholder="{{qa_edit_form_answer_placeholder}}">{{qa_edit_form_answer}}</textarea>
	<div class="qa_invalid_msg qa_ca_text_error qap_char_limit">{{qa_ca_text_error}}</div>
	<div class="qa_invalid_msg qa_ca_text_error2 qap_char_limit">{{qa_ca_text_min}}</div>
	<div class="qa_invalid_msg qa_ca_text_error3 qap_char_limit">{{qa_ca_error_url}}</div>
	<div class="qa_invalid_msg qa_ca_text_error_phone qap_char_limit">{{qa_ca_error_phone}}</div>
	<input class="qa_pa_email" placeholder="{{qa_pa_email_placeholder}}"/>

	{{#qa_admin}}
		<span class="qa_edit_form_verifier_container">
			{{qa_edit_form_verifier_label}}
			<select class="qa_edit_form_verifier">
				{{#qa_edit_form_verifiers}}
					<option value="{{id}}" {{selected}}>{{name}}</option>
				{{/qa_edit_form_verifiers}}
			</select>
		</span>
		{{#qa_edit_form_show_remove_submitter}}
		<span class="qa_edit_form_remove_submitter_container">
			<label for="qa_aq_remove_submitter">{{qa_edit_form_remove_submitter}}</label> <input type="checkbox" id="qa_aq_remove_submitter" class="qa_checkbox" />
		</span>
		{{/qa_edit_form_show_remove_submitter}}
	{{/qa_admin}}

	<span class="qa_edit_form_inactive_container">
		<label for="qa_aq_inactive">{{qa_edit_form_inactive}}</label> <input type="checkbox" id="qa_aq_inactive" class="qa_checkbox" {{qa_edit_form_inactive_val}}>
	</span>

	<div class="clearall"></div>

	{{#qa_admin}}<a class="qa_aq_delete button primary">{{qa_edit_form_delete}}</a>{{/qa_admin}}
	<a class="qa_aq_submit button primary">{{qa_edit_form_submit}}</a>
	<span class="qa_spinner"></span>
	<a class="qa_aq_cancel button secondary">{{qa_edit_form_cancel}}</a>
</div>

			</script><!--  Template for the social login/signup form  --><script id="qa_social_login_form" type="text/x-handlebars-template">
				<div class="qa_social_login_form">

	<span class="x_button"></span>

	<div>
		<span class="qa_checkmark"></span>
		<div class="qa_social_login_heading">{{qa_thanks_for_answer}}</div>
	</div>

	<div style="clear: both;"></div>

	<div class="qa_social_login_body">{{qa_social_login_form_cta}}</div>

	<div class="qa_social_login_button_container">
		<div class="qa_button social_login_button facebook_button">
			<span class="social_login_button_icon"></span>
			<span class="social_login_button_text">Facebook</span>
		</div>
		<div class="qa_button social_login_button google_button">
			<span class="social_login_button_icon"></span>
			<span class="social_login_button_text">Google</span>
		</div>
	</div>

	<div class="qa_social_login_sub">{{qa_social_login_disclaimer}}</div>

</div>

			</script><!--  Template for social login/signup confirmation  --><script id="qa_social_login_confirmation" type="text/x-handlebars-template">
				<div class="qa_social_login_confirmation">

	<span class="x_button"></span>

	<div>
		<img src="{{avatarUrl}}" class="qa_social_login_avatar" alt="user avatar">
		<div class="qa_social_login_heading">{{qa_thanks_for_social_login}}</div>
	</div>

	<div style="clear: both;"></div>

	<div class="qa_social_login_body">{{qa_info_after_social_login}}</div>

	<a class="qa_social_login_done button primary">Done</a>

</div>


			</script><div data-type="" id="qa_flag_options">
<div class="hint_box">
<ul>
<li><a data-option="answered" href="#">Already answered</a></li>
<li><a data-option="not_question" href="#">Not a question</a></li>
<li><a data-option="bad_question" href="#">Bad question</a></li>
<li><a data-option="other" href="#">Other</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>
<div data-type="" id="qa_answer_flag_options">
<div class="hint_box">
<ul></ul>
</div>
</div>
<!--  Template for rendering a desktop ArticleQuestion -->
<script id="qa_article_question_item" type="text/x-handlebars-template">
			<li class="qa_aq qa_block {{#inactive}}qa_inactive{{/inactive}}" data-aqid="{{id}}" data-cqid="{{curatedQuestion.id}}" data-caid="{{curatedQuestion.curatedAnswer.id}}" data-sqid="{{curatedQuestion.submittedId}}" data-qa_inactive="{{inactive}}" data-votes_up="{{votesUp}}" data-votes_down="{{votesDown}}" data-verifier_id="{{verifierId}}" data-submitter_id="{{submitterUserId}}">
	<div class="qa_divider"></div>

	<div class="qa_li_container">
		<div class="qa_question_tab">{{qa_question_label}}</div>
		<div class="qa_q_txt{{#qa_desktop}} question{{/qa_desktop}}">{{{curatedQuestion.text}}}</div>
		{{#qa_staff}}<div class="qa_staff_info">{{staffInfo}}</div>{{/qa_staff}}

		{{#show_editor_tools}}
		<div class="qa_editor_tools">
			<a class="qa_edit_aq">{{qa_edit}}</a>
		</div>
		{{/show_editor_tools}}

		<div class="qa_answers">
			<div class="{{qa_answerer_class}}">
			{{#qa_desktop}}
				<div class="qa_user_hover hint_box">{{#verifierId}}{{> qa_expert_hover}}{{/verifierId}}</div>
			{{/qa_desktop}}

				<div class="qa_badge"></div>

			{{#verifierId}}
				<a href="{{#formatName}}{{verifierData.name}}{{/formatName}}" class="sp_namelink qa_person_circle" target="_blank" {{#verifierData.imagePath}}style="background-image: url({{verifierData.imagePath}})"{{/verifierData.imagePath}}>
					{{^verifierData.imagePath}}<span>{{verifierData.initials}}</span>{{/verifierData.imagePath}}</a>
			{{/verifierId}}

			{{^verifierId}}
				<div class="qa_person_circle" {{#submitterAvatar}}style="background-image:url({{{submitterAvatar}}})"{{/submitterAvatar}}></div>
			{{/verifierId}}

				<div class="qa_answerer_info">
				{{#verifierId}}
					<div class="qa_user_name">
						<a href="{{#formatName}}{{verifierData.name}}{{/formatName}}" target="_blank">{{verifierData.name}}</a>
					</div>
					<div class="qa_user_title">{{{verifierData.blurb}}}</div>
				{{/verifierId}}

				{{^verifierId}}
					<div class="qa_user_name">{{{submitterDisplayName}}}</div>
				{{/verifierId}}

					<div class="qa_user_label">{{qa_answerer_label}}</div>
					{{#isTopAnswerer}}{{^qa_desktop}}<div class="qa_ta_mobile_extra"></div>{{/qa_desktop}}{{/isTopAnswerer}}
				</div>
			</div>

		{{#qa_desktop}}
			<div class="qa_answer answer">{{{curatedQuestion.curatedAnswer.text}}}</div>
			<div class="qa_answer_footer">
				{{> thumbs_qa_widget}}
				{{^qa_anon}}
				<a class="qa_ignore_answered" href="#">{{qa_flag_duplicate}}</a>
				<p class="qa_ignore_answered_thanks">Thanks!</p>
				{{/qa_anon}}
			</div>
		{{/qa_desktop}}
		{{^qa_desktop}}
		<ul>
			<li class="qa_answer">{{{curatedQuestion.curatedAnswer.text}}}</li>
		</ul>
		{{> thumbs_up_down}}
		{{/qa_desktop}}
		</div>
	</div>
</li>

		</script><!-- Template for rendering an unpatrolled QA --><!--  Template form for desktop thumbs up/down functionality  --><script id="qa_thumbs_qa_widget" type="text/x-handlebars-template">
				<div class="wh_vote_container qa_vote_buttons">
	<span class='wh_thumb_response wh_thumb_msg'>{{thumbs_response}}</span>
	<div class="qa_widget_vote_links">
		<a href="#" class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box button secondary">{{qa_thumbs_yes}}</a>
		<a href="#" class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box button secondary">{{qa_thumbs_no}}</a>
	</div>
	<div class="qa_widget_vote_buttons">
		<a href="#" class="wh_vote_down wh_vote_box">{{qa_thumbs_nohelp}} <span>{{votesDown}}</span></a>
		<a href="#" class="wh_vote_up wh_vote_box">{{qa_thumbs_help}} <span>{{votesUp}}</span></a>
	</div>
</div>



			</script><!--  Template for rendering a Top Answerers data --><script id="top_answerers_qa_widget" type="text/x-handlebars-template">
				<div class="qa_person_circle" {{#ta_image}}style="background-image:url({{{ta_image}}})"{{/ta_image}}></div>
<div class='qa_ta_name'>
	<span><a href="{{userLink}}" class="sp_namelink" target="_blank">{{userName}}</a>, {{ta_label}}</span><br />
	{{answersCount}} {{ta_answers_label}}
</div>
<div class="qa_ta_cats">
{{#topCats.0}}
	{{ta_subcats_intro}}
	{{#topCats}}<a href="{{cat_link}}">{{cat}}</a>, {{/topCats}}
	{{ta_subcats_outro}}
{{/topCats.0}}
</div>
			</script>
</div>
</div>

<div id="summary_wrapper"><div id="summary_text">
<h2>Article Summary<a href="#" id="summary_close">X</a>
</h2>
<p>To make a restaurant menu, try using a menu template in Microsoft Word, Powerpoint, or any Adobe Suite program. You can also get free templates through websites like Canva and Must Have Menus. If you want to design your own template and you're willing to pay, try using a program like iMenu, or hire a graphic designer to help turn your vision into a reality. Whichever method you use, make sure you include all of the necessary information on your menu, like the names of the dishes you'll be serving, a description of each dish, and the price. <span id="summary_last_sentence">To learn how to come up with dishes and prices for your menu, read on!</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>

    "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
    "@type": "HowTo",
    "headline": "Make a Restaurant Menu",
    "name": "Make a Restaurant Menu",
    "mainEntityOfPage": {
        "@type": "WebPage",
        "id": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu"
    },
    "image": {
        "@type": "ImageObject",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/5\/5a\/Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-24.jpg\/aid74572-v4-1200px-Make-a-Restaurant-Menu-Step-24.jpg",
        "width": 1200,
        "height": 900
    },
    "author": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "wikiHow",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",
            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",
            "https:\/\/twitter.com\/wikiHow",
            "https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/company\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/user\/WikiHow"
        ]
    },
    "aggregateRating": {
        "@type": "AggregateRating",
        "bestRating": 100,
        "ratingCount": 20,
        "ratingValue": 79
    },
    "datePublished": "2006-10-16",
    "dateModified": "2019-03-29",
    "publisher": {
        "@context": "http:\/\/schema.org",
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "wikiHow",
        "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com",
        "logo": {
            "@type": "ImageObject",
            "url": "https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/skins\/owl\/images\/wikihow_logo_name_green_60.png",
            "width": 326,
            "height": 60
        },
        "sameAs": [
            "https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/wikiHow\/",
            "https:\/\/twitter.com\/wikiHow",
            "https:\/\/www.instagram.com\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.linkedin.com\/company\/wikihow\/",
            "https:\/\/www.youtube.com\/user\/WikiHow"
        ]
    },
    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Choosing Your Menu Options",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Choose your restaurant\u2019s concept. To begin with, determine what kind of cuisine you\u2019d like to offer. Then think about who your clientele will be, and consider what price range you\u2019d like to fall in. Finally, take the location of your restaurant into consideration. Use this information to come up with a simple, concise concept for your restaurant.[1]\nTake inspiration from the restaurants and businesses around you to develop a sense of what works in this area."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Decide what your menu items will be. Make a list of the 10-12 menu items you know you can do best. This should form the basis of your menu. Select items that fit with your restaurant concept. If you are a new restaurant, avoid including more than 10-12 items at first.[2]\nIf you\u2019re restaurant is open all day, you may want to have a morning menu (breakfast\/lunch) and an evening menu (lunch\/dinner).\nDon\u2019t forget about beverages!"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Add a few high-end or speciality items. Choose 2-3 items that are a little more expensive. Try for items that fit within yout restaurant concept, but that are not offered at other places nearby.[3] Some ideas include:\n\nA premium cut of steak\nAn exotic fish\nDishes that a little harder to make, such as Spanish paella\nSpecialty entr\u00e9es for two"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Offer some \u201chouse favorites.\u201d Select 2-3 items that you know you make well, and you believe will be good seller. These should be items at mid-level price point. Label these items with a star or other symbol that indicate they are a \u201cbest seller\u201d or \u201cchef\u2019s choice.\u201d[4]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Create names for the items on your menu. Each food item on the menu will need to be called something. Marketing research has shown that customers tend to gravitate toward creative names. Rather than calling your hamburger simply \u201chamburger,\u201d why not name a speciality burger \u201cThe Mona Lisa\u201d or \u201cThe Couch Potato\u201d?[5]\nMake sure your menu names fit with the concept of your restaurant. For instance, an upscale bistro might not want comedic food names."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 6,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Write down all your menu items in a spreadsheet. Sit down and list every single item that will appear on your menu. This is important to do even if you are working from an existing menu. It will help you to best organize and categorize all of your items.\n\nThis works best if you use an Excel Spreadsheet or Google sheet.\nIf you don\u2019t have access to any kind of spreadsheet, you can do this on a sheet of paper."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 7,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Order your menu in a logical way. Determine about 3 major sections of your menu. If each section has more than 10 items, divide each section into 1-2 subsections. Then come up with a logical way to order your menu items. The most common way is chronologically, meaning that breakfast items come first and desserts come last. Place all of this info into your spreadsheet.[6] Section or subsection ideas include:\n\nBreakfast\nAppetizers\nLunch\nMain courses\nSoup and salad\nPasta\nVegetarian\nSpecialty\nBeverages and\/or cocktails"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 8,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Describe each dish in about 10 words . The food items themselves should have descriptive titles. For instance, \u201cburger\u201d doesn\u2019t sound like much, but \u201cJuicy Burger with Arugula and Horseradish Aioli\u201d will get your reader's\u2019 attention. After that, include a brief description of all the ingredients in the dish. You might say: \u201cQuarter-pound all-beef patty with arugula, creamy aioli, grilled mushrooms, ripe tomatoes, and pepper jack or Swiss cheese on a brioche bun.\u201d[7] Make a note if any of the following apply:\n\nThe dish is hotter\/spicier than most of the other dishes on the menu.\nThe dish contains any ingredients to which some people are severely allergic (e.g. peanuts).\nThe dish caters to a group with special dietary needs (vegan, vegetarian, gluten-free, etc.)"
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Pricing Your Menu",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Calculate your gross margins and markup percentages. Think about what you\u2019d like to charge for each item. Then figure out the unit cost of each menu item by adding together the cost of ingredients plus overhead costs. Subtract the unit cost of each item from your potential menu price. Divide your gross margin amount by your unit cost to get your markup percentage.[8]\nLet\u2019s say the unit cost for fried chicken is $10, and you plan to charge $16 for it. Subtract $10 from $16 to get $6.\nDivide your gross margin amount ($6) by your unit cost ($10) to get your markup percentage (60%)."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Adjust menu prices to maximize your profits. Before you finalize menu prices, keep in mind the markup percentages of these items, and what margins you should be making. Make sure your dishes are priced correctly and, if they're not, consider redoing the ingredients list or changing the recipe so you're more prepared to make a profit. In general:[9] Here are some guidelines:\n\nAppetizers and desserts will have low unit costs, and high markup percentages.\nSteak and other expensive meats will only have about a 50% markup percentage.\nPasta dishes and salads can have 80-85% markup percentages.\nAlcohol prices will vary widely. Try to keep your markup percentages between 50 and 70%."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
